user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__single:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__single (const char *param_name)
{
  if (tool_params.shared)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-S' or '--shared'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.unique)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-U' or '--unique'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.single = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No unreachable code was identified in this function. Both early returns inside the two if statements are conditional on runtime flags (tool_params.shared and tool_params.unique) and therefore potentially reachable; the remaining assignment and the final return are executed when neither condition holds, so they are reachable as well. There is no code after an unconditional return that would be dead, no mutually-exclusive compile-time constants forcing a branch to be unreachable, and no constructs (e.g. goto into a later block) that create unreachable regions. Note: potential issues such as the unusual expression "tool_params.single = ! 0;" or possible out-of-bounds access of param_name[1] (if param_name has length < 2) are not instances of unreachable code and therefore are not reported under Rule 2.1 (they may be relevant to other MISRA rules or runtime safety checks but do not indicate unreachable code).
